div.head: New Yearʼs Poems
div.p: Two occasions that regularly call for Ruskinʼs poetry to honor his father are John James Ruskinʼs May 10 birthday and New Yearʼs. Of the latter kind of occasional poem, whether inscribed for presentation on New Yearʼs Eve or on New Yearʼs Day, the earliest surviving example is “Time: Blank Verse”, which is dated ??? (see also “The Needless Alarm”: Discussion, for a poem earlier than “Time: Blank Verse”, which may have been presented as a New Yearʼs present, although it contains no formal features of an occasional poem).

div.head: The New Yearʼs Ode Tradition in the Evangelical Magazine
div.p: A likely source for modeling the New Yearʼs ode, which was available to Ruskin in the Herne Hill library, was the Evangelical Magazine, which regularly included New Yearʼs poems in the “Poetry” section for the January issue. Starting with the magazineʼs volume 1 (1793), monthly issues featured a brief one‐ to two‐page section entitled “Poetry”, consisting of contributions apparently by readers, signed with initials, aliases, or locations. These small “Poetry” sections, which were included in each monthly issue, may have served Ruskin as a model for his verse anthologies in his Red Books, collections that he entitled “Poetry” similarly to the header used for the published collections (see, e.g., MS I Poetry Anthology).

From the beginnings of the magazine, the editors encouraged readers to contribute to all departments, especially with “short pieces” such as poems (“Preface” [January 1794]). Readers responded with verse in a variety of genres—descriptive pieces, elegies, epigraphs, devotional poems, hymns, psalm paraphrases, reflections on Bible verses, doctrinal arguments, “thing” poems, as well as seasonal poems, including Christmas poems for the December issue, and New Yearʼs poems for the January issue. The final issue of volume one (December 1793) featured contributorsʼ poems on the Nativity, while the opening issue of volume two (January 1794) presented contributorsʼ poems on the New Year; and that pattern was sustained in subsequent volumes, with poems such as “Reflections at the Close of a Year” (2 1794 557) also occasionally printed in a December issue. In each annual volume, the New Year appears to have invited more verse commentary compared to Christmas (and other holy days are rarely celebrated); and New Yearʼs poems are often complemented with reflections in prose, as well. For example, in the January 1794 issue, an essay urges readers to solemnize their minds “when . . . brought to the close of the year” since, despite all “sagacity” one “cannot ascertain what events may befal me in the progress of that upon which, at present, I am about to enter!” (“Suitable Meditation for the Beginning of the Year”, 29).

The New Yearʼs poems are religious, like almost all of the poetry published in the magazine, and they tend to develop predictable themes—the shortness of time in which to live a holy life; praise of the Creator for time and the seasons; the superiority of spiritual gifts over material holiday presents. . . . Ruskinʼs New Yearʼs poems do not typically reflect these religious and admonitory themes.

A writer using the pen name Aliquis—who was among the magazineʼs first poets, with contributions to volume one—also supplied one its first New Yearʼs poems, featured in the January issue of volume 2 (Aliquis, “The New Year”). Aliquis went on to supply a poem for this occasion annually for almost four decades, the poetʼs last New Yearʼs ode being published in 1832. Earlier New Yearʼs poems by Aliquis, like those contributed by other poets to the January issues, are lyric “reflections” and “thoughts” of a speaker, looking back on shortcomings in the preceding year and resolving to do better in the coming year. Some of these poems stand out from the couplets and quatrains that characterize the mass of contributions, aspiring to formal complexity with a six‐line stanza that divides quatrameter rhyming couplets in lines 1–2 and 4–5 with rhyming trimeter lines 3 and 6. Then, with the New Yearʼs poem for 1804—notably, the year of the “Great Terror”, when British citizens watched with horror as Napoleon massed troops and flotilla on the French coast of the English Channel, in preparation for invasion—Aliquis developed the lyric form of reflection into an ode, consisting of three divisions of thought, subtitled “Reflection”, “Contrition”, and “Praise”—each section distinguished by differing metrical patterns (Aliquis, “Ode for the New Year”; see “The Defiance of War”).

From here, Aliquis goes on to produce New Yearʼs odes for every January issue, most of them in this ambitious multipart format. Accordingly, for those Januarys, Aliquisʼs odes either filled the entirety of the magazineʼs normally modest one‐ to two‐page monthly allotment to poetry or they burst the January poetry sections to take up several pages in order to allow for contributions by others, as well. Presumably, in order to have been showcased on this scale, Aliquisʼs niche performance was welcomed as a holiday tradition by the magazineʼs editors and readers. Thus, while nothing is known of Aliquisʼs identity, this poetʼs career perhaps presents an example of an amateur poet of moderate skill who achieved modest fame within a pious and respectable circle—a possible way of viewing Ruskinʼs career if he had stayed on his path of writing verse for the annuals.

When this family tradition started is uncertain. The earliest poem specifically dated 1 January is . . . and the earliest poem explicitly connected with New Yearʼs Day is . . . “The Needless Alarm” and MS I as a whole. . . . The MS III Second Poetry Anthology contains at least three New Yearʼs Poems: “Time: Blank Verse,” the previous yearʼs presentation, along with “The Sun” and “Glen of Glenfarg” (“Papa how pretty those icicles are”).

Typically the poems contained a New Yearʼs greeting, but “Glen of Glenfarg” (“Papa how pretty those icicles are”) does not, suggesting that the relevance of a given topic to the holiday may have been understood only by the family.

One possible model for this practice was the Christmas and New Yearʼs annual, containing light verse and illustration, such as Friendshipʼs Offering.[When did the family start buying annuals? Point out how anthologies following “Harry and Lucy” may be imitating this.]
For a Scottish family, New Yearʼs Day . . . (What was the celebration typically? Why New Yearʼs?) Ruskin would always treat New Yearʼs as a red‐letter day connected with writing. . . .
